BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 26, 1920

FOURTH ASSEMBLY HELD
New Eligibility Rules Announced—
News-Letter Arranges Debate on
League of Nations For Next
Assembly.

The fourth weekly massmeeting
was held in the C. E. Hall last
Thursday. The Dean opened the
meeting by' stating that all
students not present would be
held strictly responsible for all
announcements and that if the
meetings are not more regularly
attended they would be discontinued- and regular classes would
be substituted for them.
Dr. Latane next announced the
long-awaited changes in the Black
List and Eligibility Rules. Henceforth no ,student will be barred
from taking part in the athletic
and non-athletic activities of the
University provided he has received a passing mark, .6 or over,
in all courses. Li4ewise he is still
eligible with an average of .7 or
over, even though failing in one
Subject. 'These rules will be enforced automatically.
• As to the eligibility of new and
special students, and the like, no
student in any of the following
groups shall be permitted to be
a member of, or a candidate for,
any athletic team, a musical or
dramatic -club or an - editorial
board:
•
• (a) Special students.
(b) • Students on probation.
• (c) Freshmen
and
new
students with advanced standing,
during their first term in the University.
(d) Students who have a failure on their record, unless their
general average is as high as .7.
Article (c) is a long step
toward the establishment of. the
"one-year residence" rule at Hopkins and by it all new students
are
henceforth. • automatically
barred from playing football'with
the Varsity during their first
year.
Under Student Announcements
Douglas Cotton stated that the
NEWS-LETTER had arranged a discussion on the League of Nations
from both a Republican and
Democratic point of view at the
masSmeeting on Thursday,October
gs. TheRepublican speakeris to be
Col. John Philip II ill, graduate of
Johns Hopkins and Harvard Law
School, veteran of the world war,
who has long been recognized in
Baltimore as an able lawyer and
forceful speaker.

To the college man who
has a pet clothing store
You have the right idea. Next
to having a banker that trusts
you,there is no better business
than buying your things from
a merchant who is worthy of
all your confidence.
If you haven't a pet clothing
store, look up the one where
Society Brand Clothes are sold.
In the first place,it's a selected
store. We were attracted by the
merchant and he was attracted
by the style, quality,and integrity of our clothes.
Like attracts like. That is a
law.

Go to that store and ask to look
at his Society Brand Clothes.
Try on until you get the style
you like, which you surely will
in a matter of minutes.
Men remember this. Men
are not disappointed in
Society Brand Suits) They give
a very peculiar and interesting
satisfaction.
Itis the satisfaction thatcomes
from knowing—even before you
walk into the store—that you are
going te get something you will
always be glad you bought.
How's that?

HOPKINS TO BE WELL REPRESENTED IN S. A. I. A. A.
Johns Hopkins will be represented by a strong team in the
approaching S. A. I. A. A. Crosscountry Championship to be held
November 20. The scene of battle
will probably be Virginia's fine
course at Charlottesville, although
no final announcement has been
made. In anticipation of the event
a squad of over twenty men is
practicing daily at Homewood at
5 P. M.
A team of seven men will surely
be sent to Charlottesville, and, if
more men seem promising, a larger
squad will be sent. Besides Capt.
Mulliken, the following men have
been showing up well in the recent
practices: Hazeltine, a veteran of
last year's team; Bayles, from the
University of Cincinnati; Martin
Howard,from Idaho State; Jefferson, of last year's Penn Freshman
team; Norwood and Rich.
The daily practices are not only
for cross-country men, but for all
men interested in track work. The
work of developing men is so important think coach England and
Capt Mullikin, that a proposition
from Delaware College for a crosscountry meet will, in all• probability, be turned down. The authorities do not wish to take the
time from the general development
work to prepare a team especially
for such a meet.

COTILLON NOTICE.

A meeting of the Cotillon Board
was held last Thursday in the
!Tarn." The purpose of the meeting was to discuss and correct the
new constitution which is almost
completed and probably will be
adopted at the next meeting to be
held this week. It was definitely
decided to hold the first caillon
on Friday, December 23.

ORATORICAL CLUB
At:an enthusiastic and well
attended meeting of the Oratorical Club, last Friday, officers for
the scholastic year 1920-1921 were
elected, plans laid for a progressive and prosperous year, and an
instructive and interesting program arranged for the next meeting, Friday, October 29.
• The officers elected were: President, Fulton Bramble; Vice-President, George Goetz; Secretary,
Dorsey Watkins; Treasurer, Lawrence Fenneman ; Sergeant - at arms, Parker Williams; a n d
Curator, Robert Dimond.
Mr. Bramble, on assuming
charge of the meeting, remarked
on the need of presenting before
the student-body the purposes and
achievements of the Oratorical
Club. A publicity campaign was
launched and suggestions were
made to have debates and mock
trials in conjunction with the
present,proceedure of the Club.
The program for Friday, October 29, is an address by Mr. George
Goetz, on "Some Aspects of Mr.
Debs, the Man"; and a discussion
of "Mr. Debs' Political Tenets."
Mr. Bernard Ades, in support of
them, and Mr. Henry West, in
opposition.

New Site For National Academy of
Science.

A site for the new building in
Washington which is to serve as a
home for the National Academy of
Sciences and the National Research Council has recently been
obtained. It comprises the entire
block bounded by B and •C Streets
and Twenty-first and Twenty-second Streets Northwest, and faces
the Lincoln Memorial in Potomac
Park. The Academy and Council
have been enabled to secure this
admirable site, costing about
$200,000, through the generosity
of its friends and supporters.

As may be seen from the statistical report made out by the Registrar of the 'University the size
of the entering class this year and
the total undergraduate enrollment is larger than it has ever
been before.
Though there are
more academic students in the
Freshman class the three upper
classes have each a majority of
engineers. It seems that either
more men stick whbn entering the
engineering school or that the arts
and science department requires
such a high standard that more
drop out from it than-the former.
The classes grow smaller as
they near graduation, starting
with a first-year class of 242 and
ending with a senior- class of 95._
The present senior class had
nearly two hundred members
when it first donned• the black
and blue skull cap and freshman
button.
If the courses for teachers, a
number of graduate courses and
the evening courses are counted,
all of which are composed largely
of women,it may be seen that onethird of the enrollment is feminine
and that though not a co-educational institution Johns Hopkins
contributes its share to liberal
education.

UNDERGRADUATE ORCHESTRA ORGANIZED
The musical clubs took - a big
step forward when they organized
an Undergraduate Orchestra last
Thursday evening in the "Barn."
As "Mike" Bowers announced at
the last general assembly,. just
such an organization is needed at
the University to play at.times
when the Glee Club would be not
entirely suitable. At debates and
other functions of like nature, the
new orchestra will add much to
the enjoyment of the guests and
should also heighten the popularity of these various meetings.
The musical Clubs have also developed a straight Mandolin Club,
also under the direction of Mr.
Bowers.
The musical clubs have also detra will hold rehearsals every
Thursday evening in the "Barn."
The Glee Club and Mandolin Club
have chosen Tuesday evenings for
their practice.
METHODIST MISSIONARIES
NEEDED.

The Board of Foreign Missions
of the Methodist Episcopal Church
has recently requested the University Y. M. C. A. to get in touch
with as many Methodist alumni as
possible. They want not. only
Methodists, but any person who
may be interested in missionary
work, both home and abroad.
The need for missionaries i0
very great, churches of all denominations needing men who are willing to go to the home and foreign
fields to carry out their respective
program. The Methodist Church
alone needs 1618 men at present.
These needs are for men, as general church work—pastors, teachers, shoot supervisors, doctors,
nurses, and a limited number of
agricultural experts.
Any, person who knows of a
Methodist alumnus, or who is interested himself, should notify Mr.
E. Pearce Hayes, the "Y" secretary.
New Courses Offered.

Two new courses are to be added
to the curriculum of the University for the year 1920-1921. One
is a course in Chinese, to be given
two afternoons a week, and the
other in Modern Drama by Mrs.
Speare on Saturdays from 10-12.
The Romance Language Department will also add two more
courses to its schedule: Old
French Readings on Mondays at
5 P. M., in Room 205, Gilman
Hall, and Vulgar Latin on Wednesdays at the same hour. Professor D. S. Blondheim will give
these courses.

We notice this little article in
a late issue of the Haverfordian:
"FOOTBALL DANCE TO BE
HELD NOVEMBER 6.
"According to present plans, the
evening-of the victory over Johns
Hopkins, November 6, will be the
occasion of the first dance of the
college year. The dance will be
an informal affair at a reasonable
admission, managed by the Student Council in collaboration with
the' football management. More
definite details will appear later."
It is extremely interesting to
note the conceit manifested by our
worthy contemporary. Our main
and only regret will be that the
dance will have to be postponed
for several years to come, and,
therefore, we shall not have the
pleasure of shaking a shoulder
with some fair Quaker maiden.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 26, 1920

Johns Hopkins University is not
yet ready for a one-term-of-residence rule with reference to participation in athletic competition.
There is certainly no need for such
a restriction, and there is no
point in handicapping ourselves
so greatly.
This rule was put in force, at
the colleges that have this restriction, to do away with men coming
to college for the sole purpose of
playing football and dropping out
,at the end of the season. In the
first place, it is a well-known and
obvious fact that men do not come
to Hopkins for athletics alone, but
to acquire an education; and they
go out for athletics as a sideline,
and as a sideline only.
Secondly, • our undergraduate
school, from which most of the
players come, is not large enough.
The number of men going out for
athletics is'too small for any such
step.
Thirdly, none of our natural
rivals, the State teams, work
under the one-term rule, and there
is absolutely no plausible reason
for tying our hands, at the same
time allowing our opponents to
play whomever they choose.
The,:old' black-list is all right,
although we feel that it calls for
too high a standard of scholarship,
but the time is by no means ripe
for the inauguration of the oneterm rule.

Saturday's game showed the results of pitting a comparatively
green and inexperienced team
against a seasoned one. With 13
letter men and many excellent
scrubs from which to pick a team,
it is small wonder that a hardened
smooth-running machine is the
result.
The remarkable forward passing—undoubtedly the best seen on
Homewood Field in many years—
and the punting of Asplundli were
the outstanding features of the
disaster. Without these the game
would have resolved itself into a
hard, close fight, with the edge to
the Quakers. Each team was able
to gain considerable ground thru
its opponent's line.
The interference on running
back punts and kickoffs shows a
crying need for hard drilling. Not
only was the interference not leaving its feet and taking men out,
but it was crowding the man with
the ball so closely that it often resulted in being a greater let than
aid.

CLASS MEETINGS.

At .the Senior Class Meeting
Friday, the following officers were
elected: Taylor, secretary; Hubbard, treasurer, and Elmer Jones,
sergeant-at-arms., Mulligan and
Kennedy were. elected president
and.vice-president, respectively, at
•
preceding meeting.
At the meeting of the Sophomore Class, Wednesday, a call was
• issued for candidates for the class
football team and John O'Keefe
was elected manager. Emphasis
was then laid on the necessity of
rigidly enforcing Freshman RegiP
lotions. The following men were
elected to the class: Foster Morrell, P. D.- Macauley, George
Bayles, 'Henry; Position, J. L.
Chamberlain and B. T. Rich. All
men having Sophomore standing,
who, are not members of the class,
are requested to .signify 'their desire of becoming members to President Collins.
The "Freshies," too, have filled
their class offices. The result of
their election Friday is: Secretary
; Treasurer, Gieb ; SergeantsIlea;
at-arms, Morrison and Harwood;
Student Council, Morrison; Associate Editor, "Hullabaloo," Milller, and Assistant Business Manager, "Hullabaloo," Gardner.

Convenience.

The Hopkins Daily Bulletin,
which made its debut for, this
year last week, should undoubtedly prove`from now on a fixture at
the University, so well does it fill
the great need of an efficient mode
of distribution for college announcements. With the prohibitory congestion of the regular bulletin boards it is practically impossible to get anything "across"
to the mass of the student-body.
In any other manner than that
employed by the Bulletin.
The Bulletin is supported largely by the contributions of $250 by
the University and of $100 by the
Athletic Association. Each student
will be charged 50 cents toward
Its maintenance, while advertisements are expected to balance the
difference between these several
amounts and the ,$750 deemed
necessary to publish the Bulletin
throughout the year.

Field Club.

The Hopkins Field Club went
to Bay Shore Park last Saturday
on a botanical trip. They left the
corner of Howard and Franklin
streets, by trolley, at 8.30 A. M.
The entire forenoon was devoted
to searching for botanical curiosities.
The party arrived home about
1.30 P. M. The little outing was
enjoyed by all.

Princeton Plan Discussed'

The Cosmopolitan Club of the
Johns Hopkins University, sentiment for which has been carefully
fostered by the University Y. M.
C. A., had the delightful privilege
of the presence of Dr. Frank J.
Goodnow, president of the University, at their meeting last Friday evening at Central Y. M. C.
A. The meeting was preceded
by a dinner. Dr. Goodnow spoke
of the value of such an organization where men from all corners
of the globe can unite in one great
bond of friendship, likening it to
a small' league of nations. Dr.
Goodnow's chief stress was one of
warning.; In his wide experience
in foreign lands Dr. Goodnow
stated that he had found among
the foreign students who had returned home from America an
over-zealousness for American
ideals and institutions, and in
their vision of what changes they
feel should be made in their own
land, often neglect the fact that

Among most of the northern
colleges the Y. M. C. A. in 'its
Bible and Mission Study Courses
instead of securing prominent professors or, ministers to Conduct the
rather large and unwieldy classes,
conducts the whole program
Small
through the students.
classes of ,not more than fifteen
are organized and a capable
student leader is put in charge.
The student leaders meet once a
week under the guidance of a
member of the faculty,. who maps
out the best program' to be followed in the discussion of the'following week. ,
This plan has met with unexpected success wherever it has
been tried,, and its advocates are
very enthusiastic about its possibilities. The plan has not yet been
adopted at Johns Hopkins; however, it is expected that the whole
matter will be worked out at the
next meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
cabinet.

Under the direction of Captain
Griffiss the lacrosse squad has
been holding regular workouts on
the upper quadrangle for the last
two weeks. Practice is held every
Monday, Wednesday and Friday
at 4 o'clock, and quite a large
number of candidates have come
out. The many positions on the
team left vacant by graduation
offer a wonderful opportunity to
new men, who will have the usual
advantage of training under excellent coahces, the Schneisser
brothers and Reaney Wolfe.
"Father Bill" has been out several times to look the new men
over and has expressed himself
as being pleased with the number,
ability and enthusiasm of the
Freshmen who have come out.
Fall practice , will be devoted
chiefly to the development of stick
work and the mechanical part of
the game. No training will be
undertaken, but regular practice
is desired. A wall will be erected
at the athletic field against which
to throw the ball, thus making
constant practice possible.
Among the old men who will
be available this year are Captain
Griffiss, Miller, Bauernschmidt,
Turner, Cromwell, Parsons, Sadtler, Zoller, Blum and Stuart, beside , many other members of last
year's squad. With the new men,
who are sure to develop promising
material, the team should be a
worthy of former Hopkins twelves
and will doubtless add another
championship to the long string
of Black and Blue victories.
1921 Hullabaloo.

The Board of Editors of the
1921 "Hullabaloo" held its initial
meeting on Wednesday of last
week. Several assignments of
write-ups were made, the general
form and material of the "Year
Book" was decided upon, and the
contract for photographs gotten
under way. Cut-editor Hubbard
has posted signs asking for contributions to the Art Department.
Scientific Club.

A meeting of the Scientific Club
was held on Thursday, October 21,
in Room 2, Gilman Hall. Dr. L.
S. Hulbert gave a very interesting
lecture on "Desargues Theorem,"
concerning homologous triangles.
The next meeting will be held on•
Thursday, November 4. All students who are interested will
please be present.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 26, 1920
FRESHMAN SQUAD WELL
UNDER WAY
First Game Saturday With Loyola to
Be Played Before Varsity Game
With Georgetown.

The first formal game of the
Freshman football will be the contest with Loyola High, to be
played immediately preceding the
Georgetown game, October 30. A
game is also pending with Severn
School of Annapolis to precede
the St. John's .contest. The management has experienced much
difficulty in arranging a schedule
because of the late start made, but
expects to secure several more
games • before the end of the
season.
The squad now working out
under Coach "Herb" Armstrong
numbers about 25, and has shown
a marked improvement in football
fundamentals and in real teamwork. Scrimmages have already
been held with Marston Friends
and Poly, and the work of the
men studied under conditions
somewhat approaching those of a
game. Quite a few capable players have appeared, among the
more promising being Harwood,
recently elected captain; John and
George Shriver, ' Homer, Chalmers, Raleigh and Tippett.
The latest scrimmage, that with
Polytechnic, showed that the
Freshies have developed a real
team. Though at first they played
a loose and listless game, an offensive was soon developed that
swept back the opposing line with
its well-timed interference. Remembering that Poly is numbered
among the strongest squads
among local prep schools, the
Freshmen may confidently look
forward to several victories in thenext few weeks.

The Johns Hopkins Orchestra
after a most successful season last
year again organized and will endeavor to carry out a much more
lengthy and interesting schedule
than it has ever attempted since
its founding. Itresumed rehearsals
in the Concert Hall of the Peabody Institute on Tuesday, October 19. Its meetings will be
weekly hereafter.
Its conductor, Mr. Charles H.
Bochan, and its assistant conductor, Bart Wirtz, are considered among the best musicians in
the city of Baltimore.
Membership in the orchestra is
open without charge to all members of the University and to outside musicians, both men and
women. Players of wind and
string instruments who wish to
join should apply to Mr. Bochan
either at 304 East North Avenue
or at rehearsals. The orchestra
furnishes excellent opportunities
for members of the University who
wish to study serious orchestral
music.

First Installment of Dormitory Pledges
Called For.
The Treasurer of the University
has sent out to each undergraduate who pledged to subscribe to
the Memorial Fund to erect Dormitories a letter, which should
have been found in the postoffice
boxes last Tuesday. It contains
an appeal for the sums subscribed
and though very politely written
reminds every student that his
duty will not be fulfilled until he
makes the payment which he
promised to make last year. It
is to be regretted that the bills
could not have been gotten out
last February when the first payment was due, but the delay
caused by complications in records in the Dormitory Committee's office should not be made
greater because of the students'
negligence. The Treasurer of the
University will receive all money
and forward it to the proper authorities.

In order to permit the Varsity Football Team to hold longer
-and more efficient practice during
the short autumn afternoons the
management has had installed on
the lower field four 1000-Watt
electric lights.. The lamps are
placed on poles, about twenty
feet above the ground and cover
with their light the entire southeast side of the field. With this
added illumination it is now possible for the team to practice until
7 o'clock every, evening.
The lamps produce sufficient
light not only to allow the team to
hold signal practice but also to let
the first and second teams come
together in regular scrimmages.
It is also thought that even
more illuthination will be obtained
by a 'few arrangement of the reflectors, with which the managers
are now experimenting.
This innovation is only one
more step toward the development of athletics at Homewood
for which the Varsity Club is continually striving.

VOL. NXV. No. 4

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 26, 1920

FOURTH ASSEMBLY HELD
New Eligibility Rules Announced—
News-Letter Arranges Debate on
League of Nations For Next
Assembly.

The fourth weekly massmeeting
was held in the C. E. Hall last
Thursday. The Dean opened the
meeting by' stating that all
students not present would be
held strictly responsible for all
announcements and that if the
meetings are not more regularly
attended they would be discontinued- and regular classes would
be substituted for them.
Dr. Latane next announced the
long-awaited changes in the Black
List and Eligibility Rules. Henceforth no ,student will be barred
from taking part in the athletic
and non-athletic activities of the
University provided he has received a passing mark, .6 or over,
in all courses. Li4ewise he is still
eligible with an average of .7 or
over, even though failing in one
Subject. 'These rules will be enforced automatically.
• As to the eligibility of new and
special students, and the like, no
student in any of the following
groups shall be permitted to be
a member of, or a candidate for,
any athletic team, a musical or
dramatic -club or an - editorial
board:
•
• (a) Special students.
(b) • Students on probation.
• (c) Freshmen
and
new
students with advanced standing,
during their first term in the University.
(d) Students who have a failure on their record, unless their
general average is as high as .7.
Article (c) is a long step
toward the establishment of. the
"one-year residence" rule at Hopkins and by it all new students
are
henceforth. • automatically
barred from playing football'with
the Varsity during their first
year.
Under Student Announcements
Douglas Cotton stated that the
NEWS-LETTER had arranged a discussion on the League of Nations
from both a Republican and
Democratic point of view at the
masSmeeting on Thursday,October
gs. TheRepublican speakeris to be
Col. John Philip II ill, graduate of
Johns Hopkins and Harvard Law
School, veteran of the world war,
who has long been recognized in
Baltimore as an able lawyer and
forceful speaker.

HOPKINS TO BE WELL REPRESENTED IN S. A. I. A. A.
Johns Hopkins will be represented by a strong team in the
approaching S. A. I. A. A. Crosscountry Championship to be held
November 20. The scene of battle
will probably be Virginia's fine
course at Charlottesville, although
no final announcement has been
made. In anticipation of the event
a squad of over twenty men is
practicing daily at Homewood at
5 P. M.
A team of seven men will surely
be sent to Charlottesville, and, if
more men seem promising, a larger
squad will be sent. Besides Capt.
Mulliken, the following men have
been showing up well in the recent
practices: Hazeltine, a veteran of
last year's team; Bayles, from the
University of Cincinnati; Martin
Howard,from Idaho State; Jefferson, of last year's Penn Freshman
team; Norwood and Rich.
The daily practices are not only
for cross-country men, but for all
men interested in track work. The
work of developing men is so important think coach England and
Capt Mullikin, that a proposition
from Delaware College for a crosscountry meet will, in all• probability, be turned down. The authorities do not wish to take the
time from the general development
work to prepare a team especially
for such a meet.

COTILLON NOTICE.

A meeting of the Cotillon Board
was held last Thursday in the
!Tarn." The purpose of the meeting was to discuss and correct the
new constitution which is almost
completed and probably will be
adopted at the next meeting to be
held this week. It was definitely
decided to hold the first caillon
on Friday, December 23.

ORATORICAL CLUB
At:an enthusiastic and well
attended meeting of the Oratorical Club, last Friday, officers for
the scholastic year 1920-1921 were
elected, plans laid for a progressive and prosperous year, and an
instructive and interesting program arranged for the next meeting, Friday, October 29.
• The officers elected were: President, Fulton Bramble; Vice-President, George Goetz; Secretary,
Dorsey Watkins; Treasurer, Lawrence Fenneman ; Sergeant - at arms, Parker Williams; a n d
Curator, Robert Dimond.
Mr. Bramble, on assuming
charge of the meeting, remarked
on the need of presenting before
the student-body the purposes and
achievements of the Oratorical
Club. A publicity campaign was
launched and suggestions were
made to have debates and mock
trials in conjunction with the
present,proceedure of the Club.
The program for Friday, October 29, is an address by Mr. George
Goetz, on "Some Aspects of Mr.
Debs, the Man"; and a discussion
of "Mr. Debs' Political Tenets."
Mr. Bernard Ades, in support of
them, and Mr. Henry West, in
opposition.

New Site For National Academy of
Science.

A site for the new building in
Washington which is to serve as a
home for the National Academy of
Sciences and the National Research Council has recently been
obtained. It comprises the entire
block bounded by B and •C Streets
and Twenty-first and Twenty-second Streets Northwest, and faces
the Lincoln Memorial in Potomac
Park. The Academy and Council
have been enabled to secure this
admirable site, costing about
$200,000, through the generosity
of its friends and supporters.

As may be seen from the statistical report made out by the Registrar of the 'University the size
of the entering class this year and
the total undergraduate enrollment is larger than it has ever
been before.
Though there are
more academic students in the
Freshman class the three upper
classes have each a majority of
engineers. It seems that either
more men stick whbn entering the
engineering school or that the arts
and science department requires
such a high standard that more
drop out from it than-the former.
The classes grow smaller as
they near graduation, starting
with a first-year class of 242 and
ending with a senior- class of 95._
The present senior class had
nearly two hundred members
when it first donned• the black
and blue skull cap and freshman
button.
If the courses for teachers, a
number of graduate courses and
the evening courses are counted,
all of which are composed largely
of women,it may be seen that onethird of the enrollment is feminine
and that though not a co-educational institution Johns Hopkins
contributes its share to liberal
education.

UNDERGRADUATE ORCHESTRA ORGANIZED
The musical clubs took - a big
step forward when they organized
an Undergraduate Orchestra last
Thursday evening in the "Barn."
As "Mike" Bowers announced at
the last general assembly,. just
such an organization is needed at
the University to play at.times
when the Glee Club would be not
entirely suitable. At debates and
other functions of like nature, the
new orchestra will add much to
the enjoyment of the guests and
should also heighten the popularity of these various meetings.
The musical Clubs have also developed a straight Mandolin Club,
also under the direction of Mr.
Bowers.
The musical clubs have also detra will hold rehearsals every
Thursday evening in the "Barn."
The Glee Club and Mandolin Club
have chosen Tuesday evenings for
their practice.
METHODIST MISSIONARIES
NEEDED.

The Board of Foreign Missions
of the Methodist Episcopal Church
has recently requested the University Y. M. C. A. to get in touch
with as many Methodist alumni as
possible. They want not. only
Methodists, but any person who
may be interested in missionary
work, both home and abroad.
The need for missionaries i0
very great, churches of all denominations needing men who are willing to go to the home and foreign
fields to carry out their respective
program. The Methodist Church
alone needs 1618 men at present.
These needs are for men, as general church work—pastors, teachers, shoot supervisors, doctors,
nurses, and a limited number of
agricultural experts.
Any, person who knows of a
Methodist alumnus, or who is interested himself, should notify Mr.
E. Pearce Hayes, the "Y" secretary.
New Courses Offered.

Two new courses are to be added
to the curriculum of the University for the year 1920-1921. One
is a course in Chinese, to be given
two afternoons a week, and the
other in Modern Drama by Mrs.
Speare on Saturdays from 10-12.
The Romance Language Department will also add two more
courses to its schedule: Old
French Readings on Mondays at
5 P. M., in Room 205, Gilman
Hall, and Vulgar Latin on Wednesdays at the same hour. Professor D. S. Blondheim will give
these courses.

We notice this little article in
a late issue of the Haverfordian:
"FOOTBALL DANCE TO BE
HELD NOVEMBER 6.
"According to present plans, the
evening-of the victory over Johns
Hopkins, November 6, will be the
occasion of the first dance of the
college year. The dance will be
an informal affair at a reasonable
admission, managed by the Student Council in collaboration with
the' football management. More
definite details will appear later."
It is extremely interesting to
note the conceit manifested by our
worthy contemporary. Our main
and only regret will be that the
dance will have to be postponed
for several years to come, and,
therefore, we shall not have the
pleasure of shaking a shoulder
with some fair Quaker maiden.

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 26, 1920

Johns Hopkins University is not
yet ready for a one-term-of-residence rule with reference to participation in athletic competition.
There is certainly no need for such
a restriction, and there is no
point in handicapping ourselves
so greatly.
This rule was put in force, at
the colleges that have this restriction, to do away with men coming
to college for the sole purpose of
playing football and dropping out
,at the end of the season. In the
first place, it is a well-known and
obvious fact that men do not come
to Hopkins for athletics alone, but
to acquire an education; and they
go out for athletics as a sideline,
and as a sideline only.
Secondly, • our undergraduate
school, from which most of the
players come, is not large enough.
The number of men going out for
athletics is'too small for any such
step.
Thirdly, none of our natural
rivals, the State teams, work
under the one-term rule, and there
is absolutely no plausible reason
for tying our hands, at the same
time allowing our opponents to
play whomever they choose.
The,:old' black-list is all right,
although we feel that it calls for
too high a standard of scholarship,
but the time is by no means ripe
for the inauguration of the oneterm rule.

Saturday's game showed the results of pitting a comparatively
green and inexperienced team
against a seasoned one. With 13
letter men and many excellent
scrubs from which to pick a team,
it is small wonder that a hardened
smooth-running machine is the
result.
The remarkable forward passing—undoubtedly the best seen on
Homewood Field in many years—
and the punting of Asplundli were
the outstanding features of the
disaster. Without these the game
would have resolved itself into a
hard, close fight, with the edge to
the Quakers. Each team was able
to gain considerable ground thru
its opponent's line.
The interference on running
back punts and kickoffs shows a
crying need for hard drilling. Not
only was the interference not leaving its feet and taking men out,
but it was crowding the man with
the ball so closely that it often resulted in being a greater let than
aid.

Convenience.

The Hopkins Daily Bulletin,
which made its debut for, this
year last week, should undoubtedly prove`from now on a fixture at
the University, so well does it fill
the great need of an efficient mode
of distribution for college announcements. With the prohibitory congestion of the regular bulletin boards it is practically impossible to get anything "across"
to the mass of the student-body.
In any other manner than that
employed by the Bulletin.
The Bulletin is supported largely by the contributions of $250 by
the University and of $100 by the
Athletic Association. Each student
will be charged 50 cents toward
Its maintenance, while advertisements are expected to balance the
difference between these several
amounts and the ,$750 deemed
necessary to publish the Bulletin
throughout the year.

Field Club.

The Hopkins Field Club went
to Bay Shore Park last Saturday
on a botanical trip. They left the
corner of Howard and Franklin
streets, by trolley, at 8.30 A. M.
The entire forenoon was devoted
to searching for botanical curiosities.
The party arrived home about
1.30 P. M. The little outing was
enjoyed by all.

Princeton Plan Discussed'

The Cosmopolitan Club of the
Johns Hopkins University, sentiment for which has been carefully
fostered by the University Y. M.
C. A., had the delightful privilege
of the presence of Dr. Frank J.
Goodnow, president of the University, at their meeting last Friday evening at Central Y. M. C.
A. The meeting was preceded
by a dinner. Dr. Goodnow spoke
of the value of such an organization where men from all corners
of the globe can unite in one great
bond of friendship, likening it to
a small' league of nations. Dr.
Goodnow's chief stress was one of
warning.; In his wide experience
in foreign lands Dr. Goodnow
stated that he had found among
the foreign students who had returned home from America an
over-zealousness for American
ideals and institutions, and in
their vision of what changes they
feel should be made in their own
land, often neglect the fact that

Among most of the northern
colleges the Y. M. C. A. in 'its
Bible and Mission Study Courses
instead of securing prominent professors or, ministers to Conduct the
rather large and unwieldy classes,
conducts the whole program
Small
through the students.
classes of ,not more than fifteen
are organized and a capable
student leader is put in charge.
The student leaders meet once a
week under the guidance of a
member of the faculty,. who maps
out the best program' to be followed in the discussion of the'following week. ,
This plan has met with unexpected success wherever it has
been tried,, and its advocates are
very enthusiastic about its possibilities. The plan has not yet been
adopted at Johns Hopkins; however, it is expected that the whole
matter will be worked out at the
next meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
cabinet.

Under the direction of Captain
Griffiss the lacrosse squad has
been holding regular workouts on
the upper quadrangle for the last
two weeks. Practice is held every
Monday, Wednesday and Friday
at 4 o'clock, and quite a large
number of candidates have come
out. The many positions on the
team left vacant by graduation
offer a wonderful opportunity to
new men, who will have the usual
advantage of training under excellent coahces, the Schneisser
brothers and Reaney Wolfe.
"Father Bill" has been out several times to look the new men
over and has expressed himself
as being pleased with the number,
ability and enthusiasm of the
Freshmen who have come out.
Fall practice , will be devoted
chiefly to the development of stick
work and the mechanical part of
the game. No training will be
undertaken, but regular practice
is desired. A wall will be erected
at the athletic field against which
to throw the ball, thus making
constant practice possible.
Among the old men who will
be available this year are Captain
Griffiss, Miller, Bauernschmidt,
Turner, Cromwell, Parsons, Sadtler, Zoller, Blum and Stuart, beside , many other members of last
year's squad. With the new men,
who are sure to develop promising
material, the team should be a
worthy of former Hopkins twelves
and will doubtless add another
championship to the long string
of Black and Blue victories.
1921 Hullabaloo.

The Board of Editors of the
1921 "Hullabaloo" held its initial
meeting on Wednesday of last
week. Several assignments of
write-ups were made, the general
form and material of the "Year
Book" was decided upon, and the
contract for photographs gotten
under way. Cut-editor Hubbard
has posted signs asking for contributions to the Art Department.
Scientific Club.

A meeting of the Scientific Club
was held on Thursday, October 21,
in Room 2, Gilman Hall. Dr. L.
S. Hulbert gave a very interesting
lecture on "Desargues Theorem,"
concerning homologous triangles.
The next meeting will be held on•
Thursday, November 4. All students who are interested will
please be present.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 26, 1920
FRESHMAN SQUAD WELL
UNDER WAY
First Game Saturday With Loyola to
Be Played Before Varsity Game
With Georgetown.

The first formal game of the
Freshman football will be the contest with Loyola High, to be
played immediately preceding the
Georgetown game, October 30. A
game is also pending with Severn
School of Annapolis to precede
the St. John's .contest. The management has experienced much
difficulty in arranging a schedule
because of the late start made, but
expects to secure several more
games • before the end of the
season.
The squad now working out
under Coach "Herb" Armstrong
numbers about 25, and has shown
a marked improvement in football
fundamentals and in real teamwork. Scrimmages have already
been held with Marston Friends
and Poly, and the work of the
men studied under conditions
somewhat approaching those of a
game. Quite a few capable players have appeared, among the
more promising being Harwood,
recently elected captain; John and
George Shriver, ' Homer, Chalmers, Raleigh and Tippett.
The latest scrimmage, that with
Polytechnic, showed that the
Freshies have developed a real
team. Though at first they played
a loose and listless game, an offensive was soon developed that
swept back the opposing line with
its well-timed interference. Remembering that Poly is numbered
among the strongest squads
among local prep schools, the
Freshmen may confidently look
forward to several victories in thenext few weeks.

The Johns Hopkins Orchestra
after a most successful season last
year again organized and will endeavor to carry out a much more
lengthy and interesting schedule
than it has ever attempted since
its founding. Itresumed rehearsals
in the Concert Hall of the Peabody Institute on Tuesday, October 19. Its meetings will be
weekly hereafter.
Its conductor, Mr. Charles H.
Bochan, and its assistant conductor, Bart Wirtz, are considered among the best musicians in
the city of Baltimore.
Membership in the orchestra is
open without charge to all members of the University and to outside musicians, both men and
women. Players of wind and
string instruments who wish to
join should apply to Mr. Bochan
either at 304 East North Avenue
or at rehearsals. The orchestra
furnishes excellent opportunities
for members of the University who
wish to study serious orchestral
music.

First Installment of Dormitory Pledges
Called For.
The Treasurer of the University
has sent out to each undergraduate who pledged to subscribe to
the Memorial Fund to erect Dormitories a letter, which should
have been found in the postoffice
boxes last Tuesday. It contains
an appeal for the sums subscribed
and though very politely written
reminds every student that his
duty will not be fulfilled until he
makes the payment which he
promised to make last year. It
is to be regretted that the bills
could not have been gotten out
last February when the first payment was due, but the delay
caused by complications in records in the Dormitory Committee's office should not be made
greater because of the students'
negligence. The Treasurer of the
University will receive all money
and forward it to the proper authorities.

PRACTICE AT NIGHT.

In order to permit the Varsity Football Team to hold longer
-and more efficient practice during
the short autumn afternoons the
management has had installed on
the lower field four 1000-Watt
electric lights.. The lamps are
placed on poles, about twenty
feet above the ground and cover
with their light the entire southeast side of the field. With this
added illumination it is now possible for the team to practice until
7 o'clock every, evening.
The lamps produce sufficient
light not only to allow the team to
hold signal practice but also to let
the first and second teams come
together in regular scrimmages.
It is also thought that even
more illuthination will be obtained
by a 'few arrangement of the reflectors, with which the managers
are now experimenting.
This innovation is only one
more step toward the development of athletics at Homewood
for which the Varsity Club is continually striving.
